results.content: The author know his topic, but there's a critical flaw in the course description: * you don't create the application*. That's right--instead, you *download* the code, customize it a bit, and the instructor walks you through it. You do *not* create the app from scratch. If you're looking for something to show potential employers, this is not it.

response.content:
Hi James,

There's over a dozen stages of the application that you can see at various points in development.

If you want to type it out character by character you could pause the videos and do it like that. The thing is, I can't realistically do that on camera. It would have taken dozens if not 100+ hours of video due to the size of the application.

Do you really want to sit there and listen to me say "now hit the left bracket on your keyboard, then type D I V followed by the right closing bracket" for thousands of lines of HTML and Python?  You would be bored to tears.

Instead I talk about each feature of the code base, why it exists and then cover every line of code making sure you understand both why it was written and how to do it. As new sections become available, I repeat the process. Then I added a bunch of coding exercises that ask you to modify the application to gain real experience.

So far out of 1,000+ students, you're the only one who rated the course so poorly due to it not being live coded. Just about everyone prefers the current style of the course but thanks a lot for the feedback.

Also, I'm not sure what this has to do with potential employers. If you want to talk more about that, feel free to send me a message, I'll be happy to listen to your feedback to further improve the course.

response.content:
Hi Sheldon,

I see that you've only been through 15% of the course.

Sorry you didn't like it. There are quite a few coding exercises in each section that get you digging into the code and writing real world features as you progress through the course. These get introduced into the course once you know the basics. Since you stopped the course so early on, you never got a chance to experience that.

In this course, I do walk through it all in depth line by line, but instead of typing out each character I prepared the code beforehand. Then, as part of the coding exercises, you can go through and implement features.

Unfortunately I've done metrics on how long it would have taken to really type out each character out. It would have been over 80 hours of video. A course of that length is not viable (to both watch and to create). There's 4,000+ lines of Python / Flask code and thousands of lines of HTML and CSS. Those 20 hour courses simply don't cover large scale applications.

The next best thing is to break up the code base into 20 parts and explain / show how it gets built up in stages. That's what this course does, and it was the result of direct feedback from all of the students in the first version of this course. Nearly everyone requested this style of doing it.

Nick

results.content:
I like the fact that you respond to every negative review, so I'll delete my original review and be more specific here:

I think it's useful that you explained why flask and docker are good tools and why students shouldn't spend a long time researching all the alternatives.

But in the section where you first show us the flask app. You opened up a folder where code and sub folders already exist, and start to read out the lines you wrote in requirements.txt. Everyone here is very confused about the whole folder structure, which files are for docker, which files are for flask. What's the required format of requirements.txt, what's the syntax, and so on. 

You probably have a lot in mind to go over in the course, but in order to keep the course short enough, you were more like showing us your result, instead of teaching.

I ended up reading the docker and flask documentations, which are clearer.

response.content:

As for specific things like the file format of requirements.txt file, there are plenty of examples showing how to work with this file. I didn't want to spend time just reading documentation out loud. Instead this course is focused on showing how you solve real problems and build real things with Flask and Docker. Then along the way I explain every single line of code (yep all 4,000+ lines of Flask with thousands of lines of HTML, JS, CSS too). You won't find any of that in Flask's documentation, I'll assure you that.

results.content:
This is coming from a fairly experienced programmer who has written large systems that are used extensively in the real world who wanted to be able to watch a video while commuting to quickly get up to speed specifically on flask.

It's a reasonable Flask course but there is FAR too much nonsense about Docker in there. It's 50% a Flask course and 50% an advertorial for Docker (the author is a "Docker Captain") and the Instructors Docker course (the full version of which is only available from the author's website so you won't see the usual Udemy discount). He doesn't even try to tell you how to run Flask app outside a docker container (or set of docker containers when there are dependencies). Docker is a decent tool. Probably fine to run on a personal laptop provided there is nothing you care about losing on it because Docker will open stuff up to the outside world without telling you, and probably fine on a cloud instance that you are running nothing else on, but the default Docker install messes with your iptables, ip masquerading etc extensively without telling you. It prepends rules to your Iptables chain. This means that if you have secured your system because it has valuable stuff on it, and have a non-standard networking setup, your networking setup is going to go fubar and if you use something like ufw to manage your iptables, it's even worse than that because docker hides the changes it's making from your firewall management system. If you have a really simple setup, laptop with a single wifi card which does everything, things will work but note that docker is opening up your laptop to the outside world in ways that can potentially allows someone to break into it without telling you.

The author does not tell you about any of this either in this course or in the free preview of his paid docker course on Udemy. He just willy-nilly tells you to install Docker. This is bad. This seriously mars what is otherwise actually pretty decent content for someone who already knows a bit about programming, the web and python but just wants to get up and running with Flask and understand some of the patterns used by Flask developers quickly. He could just as easily have shown how to run a flask app natively and how to run redis etc when needed either on a cloud instance or in a virtual machine (which would generally not mess with your setup), or potentially show you how to install Docker in a way that won't create a security problem.

response.content:
Ashwin,

I'm sorry you're disappointed with Docker, but let me address a few of your concerns:

1. The course is definitely not 50% Flask / 50% Docker. There's over 10 hours of video and the Docker specific lectures teach you just enough about Docker to get going. It's more like 98% Flask / 2% Docker in terms of  breaking down the course by time. Also, if we didn't use Docker, even more time would have been spent setting up Virtual Machines and/or Python environments.

2. Me being a Docker Captain has nothing to do with me using Docker in this course. In fact, this course was recorded many months before I released that other Docker course. There's also thousands of students who are taking this Flask course without having to need to purchase any additional courses about Docker. I do spend just enough time on Docker in this course to get you going.

The last time I surveyed students from this course, one of their favorite aspects of the course was that we are using Docker.

3. There's plenty of students going through this course with non-standard networking set ups. Corporate firewalls, proxies, multiple network cards, and all of that fun stuff. So far there has been a total of zero (0) students who couldn't get up and running with Docker (going by what I've seen in the Q/A). You are the only one, and you also didn't reply to my latest response in the forums.

4. There are no security problems with using Docker that line up with what you're describing. I'm not sure where you're getting all of this information from. There are hundreds of large companies using Docker in production, and I've been personally using it for years in production. It's rock solid.

The problem with running Flask "natively" is you're bound to a specific OS and version. Suddenly you need to set things up differently for different machines. It's a nightmare. This is why I got started with Docker years ago, because it solves these problems (and more).

The last time I surveyed students from this course, one of their favorite aspects of the course was that we are using Docker.

3. There's plenty of students going through this course with non-standard networking set ups. Corporate firewalls, proxies, multiple network cards, and all of that fun stuff. So far there has been a total of zero (0) students who couldn't get up and running with Docker (going by what I've seen in the Q/A). You are the only one, and you also didn't reply to my latest response in the forums.

4. There are no security problems with using Docker that line up with what you're describing. I'm not sure where you're getting all of this information from. There are hundreds of large companies using Docker in production, and I've been personally using it for years in production. It's rock solid.

The problem with running Flask "natively" is you're bound to a specific OS and version. Suddenly you need to set things up differently for different machines. It's a nightmare. This is why I got started with Docker years ago, because it solves these problems (and more).

results.content_html:
This is coming from a fairly experienced programmer who has written large systems that are used extensively in the real world who wanted to be able to watch a video while commuting to quickly get up to speed specifically on flask.

It's a reasonable Flask course but there is FAR too much nonsense about Docker in there. It's 50% a Flask course and 50% an advertorial for Docker (the author is a "Docker Captain") and the Instructors Docker course (the full version of which is only available from the author's website so you won't see the usual Udemy discount). He doesn't even try to tell you how to run Flask app outside a docker container (or set of docker containers when there are dependencies). Docker is a decent tool. Probably fine to run on a personal laptop provided there is nothing you care about losing on it because Docker will open stuff up to the outside world without telling you, and probably fine on a cloud instance that you are running nothing else on, but the default Docker install messes with your iptables, ip masquerading etc extensively without telling you. It prepends rules to your Iptables chain. This means that if you have secured your system because it has valuable stuff on it, and have a non-standard networking setup, your networking setup is going to go fubar and if you use something like ufw to manage your iptables, it's even worse than that because docker hides the changes it's making from your firewall management system. If you have a really simple setup, laptop with a single wifi card which does everything, things will work but note that docker is opening up your laptop to the outside world in ways that can potentially allows someone to break into it without telling you.

The author does not tell you about any of this either in this course or in the free preview of his paid docker course on Udemy. He just willy-nilly tells you to install Docker. This is bad. This seriously mars what is otherwise actually pretty decent content for someone who already knows a bit about programming, the web and python but just wants to get up and running with Flask and understand some of the patterns used by Flask developers quickly. He could just as easily have shown how to run a flask app natively and how to run redis etc when needed either on a cloud instance or in a virtual machine (which would generally not mess with your setup), or potentially show you how to install Docker in a way that won't create a security problem.

response.content: Hi, thankfully almost nothing has changed between that version of Flask and the current version of Flask. It's a non-issue in this case. Updating to the latest version of Flask wouldn't really change anything. The app would still work the same. Flask is a micro-web framework. Most functionality comes from the libraries we use. Also, up until recently going from 0.10 to 0.11 had a 3 year gap in Flask releases. Flask isn't a fast moving framework which is a big win because it means you don't have to re-write everything every few months when a new version comes out.

results.content:
This is only the 3rd instructor I have written a review for and I have hundreds of courses across many sites. The way I identify a good technical/software course is by looking at just one thing.

Do they provide any information on Software Testing? 
You will be surprised how few actually include tests. This one does. It's not TDD but Nick explains the Tests first thing. If you come to work anywhere in the real world and can't write tests, you better get the heck out.

Is it worth the money? Absolutely.
I have made Flask apps on ad hoc projects but nothing full blown. I learned Rails with much pain and google searches and mentoring. It took an year just to be able to catch up with my experienced team. I wanted to make a full blow Flask app but what stopped me was the hundreds of hours of searching and trial-and-error to get everything right. So it saved me about 400 hours of that.  Yes. thats how long it takes to figure this out on your own.

How does it compare to other flask courses?
I don't know. they dont talk about writing tests, so I ignore them.

bonus: the code Nick is giving away is worth thousands. You can use it as template to bootstrap any project. I was quoted over 2500$ for a PHP based app prototype for something similar which I knew I was gonna hate and would be of sub-par quality. This is production ready and good quality code. I do code reviews at work and this is well structured, good library choices, including added features missing from vanilla Flask extensions.

cons: It's not for everyone. If you can't do some of the research (not lots) and try the exercises on your own you will not get anything out of it. I created my own project using his template that I modify as I go along. That helps build the muscle memory he talk about.
I haven't reached ORM yet, but I believe ORM could use a bit more depth, just looking at highlights here.

I am writing this to let Nick know you're underselling this. There is no equal course for full stack anywhere that is as good as this!

response.content:
Hi Abhishek, Wow, thanks so much for taking the time out to write this. It's feedback like this which makes everything worth it for me because I enjoy sharing what I've learned with others.

As for ORM coverage, we do go over a bunch of common data model relationships through out the course, but since this is an "uncover features as we go" type of course, you won't see some of those until you make it towards the end of building the app.

Also for the record, I've billed out $10,000+ for the type of application that we build in this course from contract work on multiple occasions. Of course those apps had more business logic, but it was for the core concepts included here (setting up a subscription site that handles payment). That's how I ended up making this course, from writing apps like this time and time again.

You will be surprised how few actually include tests. This one does. It's not TDD but Nick explains the Tests first thing. If you come to work anywhere in the real world and can't write tests, you better get the heck out.

Is it worth the money? Absolutely.
I have made Flask apps on ad hoc projects but nothing full blown. I learned Rails with much pain and google searches and mentoring. It took an year just to be able to catch up with my experienced team. I wanted to make a full blow Flask app but what stopped me was the hundreds of hours of searching and trial-and-error to get everything right. So it saved me about 400 hours of that. Yes. thats how long it takes to figure this out on your own.

How does it compare to other flask courses?
I don't know. they dont talk about writing tests, so I ignore them.

bonus: the code Nick is giving away is worth thousands. You can use it as template to bootstrap any project. I was quoted over 2500$ for a PHP based app prototype for something similar which I knew I was gonna hate and would be of sub-par quality. This is production ready and good quality code. I do code reviews at work and this is well structured, good library choices, including added features missing from vanilla Flask extensions.

cons: It's not for everyone. If you can't do some of the research (not lots) and try the exercises on your own you will not get anything out of it. I created my own project using his template that I modify as I go along. That helps build the muscle memory he talk about.
I haven't reached ORM yet, but I believe ORM could use a bit more depth, just looking at highlights here.

I am writing this to let Nick know you're underselling this. There is no equal course for full stack anywhere that is as good as this!

I started to watch with course, because I got hooked by complete functioning website with a game as a course result. When I got to about half of the course I understood that it is too complicated to fresh webdev. I’m data scientist and know python well. That’s it. In this course you don’t use just python, you use all range of web technologies. This course is about full stack web development.

Anyway I got a nice understanding of how modern websites are build of. For me this course is an overview of technology that I should learn. Also I will come back to this course when I get more gain more experience in webdev to copy Nick workflow and best practices.

List of technologies (not complete):

-docker
- gunicorn
- redis
- celery
- jinja2
- flask
- postgres
- Click - very handful tool for creating user defined command line interfaces.
- java script, because you build front-end in this course.

I learnt that Flask is not something that build website instead of you. Flask helps you to get all technologies work together and get a full control over them. You have to know html, css, java script, databases to build a website.

I will continue my webdev journey by watch or read something simpler about webdev using python and will check with course for some practical advice. Also I really liked Docker - it’s very useful tool for all computer professionals.

results.content: Nick’s course Build a SAAS App with Flask, is a good choice for software developers who are transitioning towards DevOps roles.  Here, we will delve into the realm of a (micro)service architecture, using skills such as refractoring, to write better code.   You will create CLI interpreters that will make old development jobs seamless and super-fast, and Docker, will be the choice for running multiple apps and worker tasks, with technologies such as Redis and Celery.  And if you haven’t tried Flask before, perhaps now is the time, because I have found it is a highly extensive framework to work with, that also has a library of well-written extensions that will make the workload less.

response.content:
Hi Jason,

Sorry you didn't like the course. Udemy will give you a no questions asked refund if you request it.

By the way, as you progress through the course there are a number of coding exercises where I give you real world feature requests to implement so that you get that hands on experience.

The problem with building a non-toy app is it has a ton of code (thousands of lines). Realistically it would have taken 100+ hours of video to build it line by line. Instead, I go over every single line of the code base in great detail, so you understand the "why" and get to see the "how".

So rather than code it character by character, there's 15 distinct copies of the code base at various stages of development. This lets you see how it grows from a single app.py file to the finished app in stages.

results.content:
Unfortunately this is not a course once you watch the instructor explaining the already-created application code. It feels like the instructor didn't want to make an extra effort to develop the application alongside the student.

Moreover, it is extremely fast-paced and the instructor skips many explanations.

I'm sorry but there is no way to recommend this course as it is. All the time we have to check the docs and other resources because it is not even said the basics of aspects like docker, testing, pytest, and so on. If it is not the focus of the course, the instructor should make effort on things it is capable of giving in-depth explanations. Bloating the course with other topics not related to flask is not the path.

response.content:
Hey Victor,

It's not really possible to build a 4,000+ line Flask app together line by line with an additional 1000s of lines of HTML, JS and CSS on top. I theorycrafted how long it would have taken there and would have been over 60 hours of video.  Instead it's broke up into many different stages (separate folders).

Every line of code is talked about in great detail if you watch the full course (I see you only completed a small portion of the course). For example, when we're 7 hours deep in the course and we encounter another Flask route. I don't explain what routes are in detail because we already did that during the first hour of content, but I would explain what that specific route does in detail (ie. the contents of the route). Were you skipping around?

Not much time at all is spent on other topics which you can see from the course's content. There's about 10 hours of total content and only about 20 minutes of that is spent on Docker (and you learn everything you need to run it, so far I've had 0 complaints about people feeling like they were lost with Docker). If I didn't use Docker then you would have spent more than 20 minutes installing Python, virtualenv and trying to set up a dev environment manually. The rest is purely focused on building web apps with Flask.

There's also a ton of test coverage and I go over testing in great detail.

To wrap things up there's over a dozen real life feature request coding challenges to get your hands dirty with adding things to the app we build up in the course. You'll have dozens of hours of extra content if you do these optional homework assignments. Those start off easy early on in the course and ramp up in difficulty towards the end.

Most people are really enjoying the course. If you're unhappy, feel free to ask Udemy for a refund.

results.content:
In selecting a course, I typically look for hands on coding opportunities that utilize a follow-along methodology, and with this being titled, The Build a SAAS App with Flask Course title, my expectations were set.  I was wrong, and for good reason.  Nick Janetakis dismantles the mysteries of using the Flask framework for application development, by teaching you the functional topology of a properly designed Flask app, with thorough, step-by-step explanations at each stage in the complex project’s development.  Be prepared, this course covers numerous topics in a short period of time, it is a lot of information and if you are not familiar with Flask, which I was not, do yourself a huge favor and study the information on the links Nick provides – it will assuredly enhance your understanding and reduce the time it takes you to understand each section.  One more thing – production standards were not lacking.  Nick’s voice-over tracks had consistent levels, they were clean and never got in the way of the instruction.  Thanks, Nick, I’m glad I saw this through to the end!

** UPDATE **
Now that I've had a chance to put what I learned into practice, all I can say is WOW!  I am changing my initial rating to 5-Stars.  If there's ANY Flask course you take, take this one first.  I don't remember how much I paid, but it should have been much more.

results.content: This is basically a Docker class and all the Flask has been pre-written.  There are issues with Docker and Mac I couldn't resolve.

response.content:
Hi,

Not sure what you mean by that. There is 1 tiny lecture that goes over installing Docker on any major OS in about 5 minutes, then a few lectures giving you a quick run down on how to interact with Docker so you're not left in the dark. There's around 20 minutes of Docker specific content in 10 hours of videos.

I also didn't see you open any issues in the forums to help resolve your issue. There's hundreds of people taking the course successfully on OSX as we speak.

The code base is broken up into over a dozen stages. You're correct in that we don't type it out together character by character. There's over 4,000 lines of just Flask code and thousands of lines of HTML. It would have taken over 100 hours to type it together in real time, instead I explain every single line of code in the project and you can see how it goes from a single app.py file to the end result.

A number of people have already either landed Flask jobs due to the course or have been successfully building and launching their own products due to what they learned in this course.

I'm sorry you haven't gotten past the first few minutes of the course due to not being able to install Docker, I'll gladly help you if you post the problem in the forum.

results.content:
An AMAZING start to learning how to build a SaaS app and how to use Flask from beginning to end.

This course, in reality, is worth over $500 and I'd go far as to say I'd pay $1000 or more for it just for the sheer amount of content, code, and how responsive Nick is to help with questions and problems.

I would say I was a beginner/intermediate level Python programmer and was basically brand new to web dev besides knowing HTML, CSS, and Bootstrap. If you're with me, this course is great to learn all the ins and outs. It's gonna be overwhelming at first but it's totally worth it in the end.

I found the most success out of this course by going through it once and skipping the sections I didn't immediately need for the SaaS app I had in mind like i18n, then going back, building my app while reviewing the sections as I moved along.

I'm far from finished but I would've totally been lost without this course.

results.content:
Nick has created a fantastic resource for using Flask.
If you are serious about learning web development and taking a deep-dive with Flask; buy this course.
It is worth every penny and more.
And that is just for the content! 


Beyond that Nick is also an excellent teacher.
The content he has created is lean but loaded with useful and practical information.
When I started the course I had several months of Flask experience under my belt.
For me I was interested in certain aspects of the course, i.e. Docker.
So when I started, I was jumping around a lot. 


Though the course is organized to be followed linearly, I had great success in jumping around.
Nick covers nearly everything in the code base and explains why it is there.
So it is really not much trouble to extract the parts you are interested in and start building your own project.
That said, I feel like I've learned something from every lesson I've watched.
Even when I felt like I was in a "back to the basics" situation, I still found myself learning new stuff.


Even more, Nick has always been quick to respond my questions.
I've never had a message fall through the cracks with Nick.
Nick has become an invaluable mentor for me.
In fact, he emailed me with a job opportunity, which I successfully applied for.
Without Nick, I wouldn't have landed my new job as a back-end web developer!

results.content:
I like that the author found a niche, which is that few tutorials and YouTube videos show you in-depth, production, projects. That part is awesome. However, the reality is that much of the code has been written for you. And I, personally, don't learn that way. He admits the fact that such a complex app is almost impossible to write as a tutorial, due to time constraints and/or complexity, however, I dislike having to work off of previously written source code, even if it is a time saving measure, I feel like the concepts may be important for an amateur. 

I would NOT recommend this course for a beginner, considering the fact that there are concepts that may complicate your learning experience, such as Docker, which isn't really necessary. I think it's more of an intermediate-advanced tool, because it adds another layer of complexity to an already moving machine; something that beginners shouldn't have to worry about in their stage.

Other than that, its a solid course.

response.content:
Hi,

Thanks for the feedback, but keep in mind if we didn't use Docker then you would need to learn how to set up Python, virtualenv, Honcho, Redis, Postgres and a few other tools directly on your OS which would be different for everyone. It would take -much- longer to set up everything and get going with Flask without Docker.

Docker bypasses all of those problems and gives you a single way to run your apps on any major platform.  While it's not 100% necessary, it's a very very very good idea to use it, otherwise you're stuck having to follow a 50+ command guide on getting things up and running on your own. Instead, with Docker, all you have to do is install it and run 1 command.

I'm not sure how far along you are into the course but there are over 30 hours worth of homework assignments where you get to apply everything you've learned in each section by adding real features to the application.

Every line is covered. Also the source code in itself has value. There's years worth of well tested battle hardened code that you can directly use in your projects. On top of that you get full time support to ask as many questions as you want that's related to the course.

There's also 30+ hours of assignments to add new features into the code base if you want to get experience writing code and thinking about how to implement real life features. There's one of these challenges at the end of every section.
